Wagner Graduate School of Public Service        School of Continuing and Professional Studies        School of Law        School of Medicine        School of Social Work        Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development        Tisch School of the Arts                                                   New York University              New York University              NYU Bookstores                                                        Bookstore         Computer Store         NYU Catalog and Ordering       Gift Cards       Shipping       Deferred Payment Plan       Personal Order Form       Department Software Licensing       Service Department             NYU Clothing & Gifts       Faculty Services       Textbooks                                                       The NYU Computer Store Online contains special pricing which requires faculty, staff and registered students to provide either their 'netID' or 'NYU ID.'      Both can be found on the back of your NYU ID Card.   Note on Web Browsers     This site supports the current versions of Internet Explorer and Firefox on Windows, and Safari and Firefox on the Mac. Popups must be enabled for this NYU site to work properly. Please ensure they are before you proceed. If you are not sure, or need instructions, please  click here.    GOOGLE CHROME USERS:   For this site to work properly, you must click the shield icon in the navigation toolbar and choose 'LOAD ANYWAY'.    » Computer Store Return Policy              Enter your 'netID' or 'NYU ID'                    I agree to the Terms and Conditions                Note: Newly accepted, but not yet registered, students may still utilize these special prices and should only use their 'NYU ID' to access this portion of the website.      If you are having trouble authenticating with your NYU ID please email computer.store@nyu.edu with your name, email address, NYU ID, and phone number.                        Terms and Conditions: The NYU Computer Store makes computer hardware and software available at discounted educational prices. In general you may only purchase computer equipment at these educational prices if you are a member of the NYU community and if you represent that the equipment purchased is for your personal, educational, and/or research use and not for business, resale, or any other purpose.      Newly Accepted Students:     (New students who do not have ID cards, can go to http://start.nyu.edu to get their NET ID. You will need to provide your Social Security number or your NYU ID number, which was provided to you in your acceptance materials.)          If you have an ID card Your NYU ID is on the Back of the Card.          Additional Apple Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell Apple Computer equipment to: NYU faculty; students enrolled in a course of study leading to a degree or certificate from NYU; entering freshman who have been accepted by NYU and who have responded by stating their intent to enroll at NYU; and permanent NYU staff, other than contractors or consultants, who are directly associated with NYU's academic mission.          Qualified customers can only purchase one desktop, one laptop, two displays, two iPods, two iSights and two of each software title per academic year.          Additional Dell Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell Dell computer equipment to NYU faculty or staff who are eligible for NYU's minimum employment benefits. The NYU Computer Store may only sell Dell computer equipment to NYU students who are enrolled for instruction or have received a letter of acceptance for enrollment with NYU.          Additional IBM Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell IBM computer equipment to: NYU faculty, staff, alumni and students enrolled in a course of study leading to a degree from NYU, or a course of study at NYU which is at least one year long and leading to a certificate from NYU, or a course of study at NYU which is at least three months long and required for the maintenance of professional certification.          Additional Hewlett Packard Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell Hewlett Packard computer equipment to NYU faculty, staff, and students.          All Hardware/Software Purchase Conditions New York University disclaims all warranties, express or limited, with respect to the sales of computer hardware or software, including without limitation, implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose.          Please consider your purchases carefully and in consultation with one of our staff. All sales are final at the time of pick up or delivery. If an item is not in stock at the time of order, we will attempt to assure delivery in a timely manner. However, the NYU Computer Store cannot warrant or guarantee a specific delivery date.          Apple, Dell, IBM, Epson and Hewlett Packard machines are covered by the manufacturer's warranty. These will be honored at any of their authorized service centers. The NYU Computer Store is an authorized Apple, Dell, and IBM repair center. Some software is pre loaded on the hard drive. This software is not covered by the manufacturer's warranty, and may not include documentation or back-up copies. Please contact us if you need service or support.          Disclaimer:     Product Pricing, specifications, availability and terms of offers may change without notice. Errors when identified will be corrected and you will be notified of the the corrected pricing, specifications, availability and terms of offers that relate to your specific order.      (Hide Terms and Conditions)                                         Computer Store : 242 Greene Street, New York, NY 10003 | (212) 998-44672

Welcome - NYU Computer Science Department                                                                         Search                                                  go                         Location          Contacts      Directions      NYC Information            Admissions          Undergraduate Admissions      Graduate Admissions           People           Faculty        Researchers/Visitors      Administration/Staff      Students: PhD / MS      Alumni / In Memoriam             Research           Research Areas      Tech Reports      Theses: PhD / MS        Faculty Recognition      Student Recognition           Education           Undergraduate Program      Graduate Program : PhD / MS        Courses      Office Hours           News / Events           Colloquia        Calendar: Grad / Undergrad           Job Openings           Faculty Positions             Links           Libraries      Student Organizations      CIMS Computing                                                                                                                                                                     Welcome                              Welcome to NYU's Computer Science Department, part of the world-famous Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. Our department has considerably expanded over the past few years, adding many outstanding faculty with diverse research interests. We are proud of our strong research and educational connections to other departments and schools at NYU, including the departments of Mathematics, Chemistry, Physics, and Biology; the Center for Neural Science; the Stern School of Business; the Tisch School of the Arts; the Wagner School of Public Service; and the NYU School of Medicine.         Our undergraduate majors and MS students have numerous interesting and well-paying employment opportunities at major corporations in New York City and vicinity. Our PhD graduates are employed in a broad spectrum of academic and industrial research positions.              News and Highlights                        Remembering Prof. Jack Schwartz   One of the founders of the NYU Computer Science Department, Jack Schwartz, is remembered in a collection of reminiscences in the current issue of the Notices of the American Mathematical Society, including a contribution from Professor Emeritus Martin Davis.               2014-2015 Dean's Outstanding Dissertation Award   Dr. Russell Power has been awarded the 2014-2015 Dean's Outstanding Dissertation Award in the Sciences for his thesis "Building efficient distributed in-memory systems". His advisor was Jinyang Li. Congratulations!               2015 NYUAD Annual Hackathon   The fourth Annual NYUAD Hackathon for Social Good in the Arab World , organized by Professor Sana Odeh, took place April 10-12. It drew over 100 students from a dozen countries worldwide.    For more news about the hackaton, see here .               ACM Fellow   Juliana Freire has been named a Fellow of ACM for contributions to provenance management research and technology, and computational reproducibility. Congratulations!    See the press release for more information.               ACM Distinguished Scientist   Clark Barrett has been named a 2014 Distinguished Scientist by the ACM. Congratulations!               2015 IEEE Donald G. Fink Award   Theodore Rappaport and his students have been awarded the 2015 IEEE Donald G. Fink Award for the outstanding survey, review, or tutorial paper in IEEE publications. Congratulations!              <<More News>>                    Learning and modeling the circuits that operate life: The Bonneau lab aims to learn large biological networks directly from genomics data (genomics =3D very scalable biology experiments). Our recent work, as part of collaborative teams of systems biologists and  computational biologists, has recently resulted in genome-wide models that are capable of simulating the functioning of the genome in real time (Bonneau, et. al, 2006, Cell). Dr. Bonneau's lab develops new algorithms that attempt to learn the regulatory networks (their topology and dynamical parameters) that are at the core of biological systems. This work was featured in a 2008 Discover Article, where Dr. Bonneau was selected as one of the top 20 scientists under 40. This work is collaborative work that relies on NYU's local expertise in Machine Learning, Modeling complex systems and their dynamics, and Genomics.  Links:   Bonneau Lab     With Ph.D. student Eugene Weinstein and Google researcher Pedro Moreno, Mehryar Mohri is working on audio fingerprinting techniques that enable computers to recognize songs. This work represents songs in terms of "music phonemes", elementary units of music sound that are learned from data, and uses weighted finite-state transducers to construct a compact and efficient index of a large database of songs. The image depicts an example of such a transducer. As a result, songs can be recognized quickly and accurately when only a recording of a short "audio snippet" is available and even when the recording is distorted. The group has created a working system with a database of 15,000 songs. Moreover, it has proven new bounds on the size of the indexing finite automata used that guarantee the compactness of this representation as the number of songs indexed increases and suggests that their techniques scale to much larger song data sets.   Links:   Example                                     Events                                           Check the Colloquia for more scheduled talks.            Check the CIMS Weekly Bulletin for more events.                                         top | contact webmaster@cs.nyu.edu

Qualified customers can only purchase one desktop, one laptop, two displays, two iPods, two iSights and two of each software title per academic year.          Additional Dell Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell Dell computer equipment to NYU faculty or staff who are eligible for NYU's minimum employment benefits. The NYU Computer Store may only sell Dell computer equipment to NYU students who are enrolled for instruction or have received a letter of acceptance for enrollment with NYU.          Additional IBM Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell IBM computer equipment to: NYU faculty, staff, alumni and students enrolled in a course of study leading to a degree from NYU, or a course of study at NYU which is at least one year long and leading to a certificate from NYU, or a course of study at NYU which is at least three months long and required for the maintenance of professional certification.          Additional Hewlett Packard Specific Conditions:     The NYU Computer Store may only sell Hewlett Packard computer equipment to NYU faculty, staff, and students. Apple, Dell, IBM, Epson and Hewlett Packard machines are covered by the manufacturer's warranty. These will be honored at any of their authorized service centers. Welcome - NYU Computer Science Department                                                                         Search                                                  go                         Location          Contacts      Directions      NYC Information            Admissions          Undergraduate Admissions      Graduate Admissions           People           Faculty        Researchers/Visitors      Administration/Staff      Students: PhD / MS      Alumni / In Memoriam             Research           Research Areas      Tech Reports      Theses: PhD / MS        Faculty Recognition      Student Recognition           Education           Undergraduate Program      Graduate Program : PhD / MS        Courses      Office Hours           News / Events           Colloquia        Calendar: Grad / Undergrad           Job Openings           Faculty Positions             Links           Libraries      Student Organizations      CIMS Computing                                                                                                                                                                     Welcome                              Welcome to NYU's Computer Science Department, part of the world-famous Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. Our department has considerably expanded over the past few years, adding many outstanding faculty with diverse research interests. We are proud of our strong research and educational connections to other departments and schools at NYU, including the departments of Mathematics, Chemistry, Physics, and Biology; the Center for Neural Science; the Stern School of Business; the Tisch School of the Arts; the Wagner School of Public Service; and the NYU School of Medicine.         Our undergraduate majors and MS students have numerous interesting and well-paying employment opportunities at major corporations in New York City and vicinity. Our PhD graduates are employed in a broad spectrum of academic and industrial research positions.              News and Highlights                        Remembering Prof. Jack Schwartz   One of the founders of the NYU Computer Science Department, Jack Schwartz, is remembered in a collection of reminiscences in the current issue of the Notices of the American Mathematical Society, including a contribution from Professor Emeritus Martin Davis.               2014-2015 Dean's Outstanding Dissertation Award   Dr. Russell Power has been awarded the 2014-2015 Dean's Outstanding Dissertation Award in the Sciences for his thesis "Building efficient distributed in-memory systems". His advisor was Jinyang Li. Congratulations!               2015 NYUAD Annual Hackathon   The fourth Annual NYUAD Hackathon for Social Good in the Arab World , organized by Professor Sana Odeh, took place April 10-12. It drew over 100 students from a dozen countries worldwide.    For more news about the hackathon, see here .               ACM Fellow   Juliana Freire has been named a Fellow of ACM for contributions to provenance management research and technology, and computational reproducibility. Congratulations!    See the press release for more information.               ACM Distinguished Scientist   Clark Barrett has been named a 2014 Distinguished Scientist by the ACM. Congratulations!               2015 IEEE Donald G. Fink Award   Theodore Rappaport and his students have been awarded the 2015 IEEE Donald G. Fink Award for the outstanding survey, review, or tutorial paper in IEEE publications. Congratulations!              <<More News>>                    Learning and modeling the circuits that operate life: The Bonneau lab aims to learn large biological networks directly from genomics data (genomics =3D very scalable biology experiments). Our recent work, as part of collaborative teams of systems biologists and  computational biologists, has recently resulted in genome-wide models that are capable of simulating the functioning of the genome in real time (Bonneau, et. al, 2006, Cell). Dr. Bonneau's lab develops new algorithms that attempt to learn the regulatory networks (their topology and dynamical parameters) that are at the core of biological systems. This work was featured in a 2008 Discover Article, where Dr. Bonneau was selected as one of the top 20 scientists under 40. This work is collaborative work that relies on NYU's local expertise in Machine Learning, Modeling complex systems and their dynamics, and Genomics.  Links:   Bonneau Lab     With Ph.D. student Eugene Weinstein and Google researcher Pedro Moreno, Mehryar Mohri is working on audio fingerprinting techniques that enable computers to recognize songs. This work represents songs in terms of "music phonemes", elementary units of music sound that are learned from data, and uses weighted finite-state transducers to construct a compact and efficient index of a large database of songs. The image depicts an example of such a transducer. As a result, songs can be recognized quickly and accurately when only a recording of a short "audio snippet" is available and even when the recording is distorted. The group has created a working system with a database of 15,000 songs. Moreover, it has proven new bounds on the size of the indexing finite automata used that guarantee the compactness of this representation as the number of songs indexed increases and suggests that their techniques scale to much larger song data sets.
